lines.text: God... if there is a God... if you're a man or a woman... if you're listening, I'd really, really like a family. My dad says that will only happen if the Angels win the pennant. The baseball team, I mean. So, maybe you can help them win a little. Amen. Oh, a-woman, too.
There's a thing called "*talent*"! They don't have it!

[Roger and JP are in their beds]
Roger?
What?
Are you asleep?
If I was sleeping, how would I be talking to you?
You could be sleep-talking.
Look, I'll give you a dime tomorrow if you don't say another word.
Okay.
[Roger snuggles more into the covers, just starting to sleep]
Roger?

[sighs loudly]
You can forget that dime.
Dad, um - when we gonna be a family again?
Where I'm sitting... ,
[looks at the stadium]
I'd say when the Angels win the pennant. You stay out of trouble, son.
[starts motorcycle engine and drives away]
You believe there's real angels?
I know it sounds crazy.
[last lines]
We're always watching.
[taking a picture with George Knox and Roger]
It looks like a prison photo. Would either of you mind smiling? The team did just win.
It was a mistake. This team can't win.
They won because there were angels out there.
Huh?
Real ones. I saw them. Two angels came out of the sky and they picked up Ben Williams and another angel hit Messmer's home run. That's why the bat broke.
Great. A psycho kid. David, you'd think they'd screen these people.
It's true. Ask Williams about it or Messmer. They'll tell you something's going on. You'll see.

[the Angels have lost their fifteenth straight game]
One more loss! One more loss which could've been a win! And you call yourselves professionals. I have never, ever seen a worse group of twenty-five players! You don't *think* as a team, you don't *play* as a team, you don't even LOSE as a team! You've all got your heads so far up your butts, you can't even see the light of day! One more loss and I'll, and I'll do this...
[throws a chair at a rack of balls and bats]
to each and every one of you!

[stands]
Um, excuse me. I'd like to say something on behalf of George Knox.
What's your name? What's your business here?

My name is Maggie Nelson. I take care of foster kids. One of these boys is the child who can see angels. He could stand up right now and tell you what's going on and I'd know you'd just laugh at him. But, when a professional football player drops to one knee to thank God for making a touchdown, nobody laughs at that. Or when a pitcher crosses himself before going to the mound, no one laughs at that either. It's like your saying it's okay to believe in God, but it's not okay to believe in angels. Now, I thought that they were on the same team.
Is it your belief, ma'am, that angels play baseball?
an angel. You've got to have faith. You've got to believe. You have to look inside yourself. The footprints of an angel are love, and where there is love, miraculous things can happen. I've seen it.
[sits]
I won't play for anyone but George Knox. I believe in him.

[stands]
That goes for me, too.
[stands and nods in agreement]
Thank you. All of you.
Hey, let's keep the profanity down!
HUH?
I mean it! No swearing!
That eliminates all speech for most of the team.
And for dessert... Jello.
Yay!
It's not really Jello, it's cats' brains with food coloring. She kills them at night and feeds it to us to save money.
[JP makes a disgusted face]
Shut up, Miguel!
Roger! We do not use those words in this house. And you know I would never put food coloring on my cat brains.
[ruffles Miguel's hair]
Look! It's God's thumbnail!
Who are you?
Just call me Al. No one can see me or hear me but you.
David, I need a drink.
Which of these drinks?
I don't want that. I want something else.
What else?
Uh... coffee.
You drink coffee?
Yeah, of course. All the time.
Yeah, all the time! What do you think we are? Little kids or something? Now give me a cup or I'll scream!
How do you take it?
In cups.
I'm glad you're here! I was afraid no one was going to show up today, since everybody knows about the angels.
Nobody's coming. Championships have to be won on their own. It's a rule.
Then why are you here?

[gestures to Clark]
I came to check up on Mel. He's coming up soon. Going to be one of us.
You mean he's...
Ah, he's smoked for years. Always a mistake. He's got 6 months left, doesn't even know anything's wrong yet.
No!
Oh, don't you worry. He's well taken care of. You concentrate on your own life now. We are expecting great things from you kid. We'll all be watching, you remember that.
[slowly dissolves away]
Even though you can't see us, we're always watching.
You used to be Mel Clark?
Yeah. I used to be.

[hands JP a business card]
Hey. I'm Ranch Wilder. The voice of the Angels.
I know who you are. I heard you on the radio. You sure do have a big chin.
Everybody's a critic.
[the players are touching a post as they walk into the locker room]
Why do you idiots do that after you've lost?
It's for good luck, man.
After 15 straight losses, I say we find something else to rub.
How about Triscuitt's head?
Hey, don't even think about touching me anywhere.

[stops reaching for it]
Fatty pants.
You know, maybe we should do this *before* we lose.
Whit Bass takes the mound with his oddball antics that are now well known to the fans.
That's right, Ranch. This season alone we've seen him lick dirt, eat bugs, and floss his catcher's teeth in the dugout.

[switches off Wally's mike and on his own]
None of that, may I add, seems to have helped his pitching. He's 2 and 11.
I'd say the fans seem a little bouncier today, wouldn't you, Wally?
That's right, Ranch. As we saw last game...

[Turns off Wally's mike for the second time]
Easy Wally, less is more.
Ranch?
[Ranch turns to face him, grinning as though he supported the play]
You're fired.
[exits]
You can't fire me! I have got a contract! I AM RANCH WILDER!

[cheerfully]
Easy, Ranch. Less is more.
I want you all here, in uniform, at 9 tomorrow! We're going back to work on fundamentals!
[the team groans]
Fundamentals? In the middle of the season?
I thought the game started at *1*.
It *does* start at 1. And you're a jack-ass!
No, I'm a pitcher.
[Knox storms off]
Well, you're a pitcher and a jack-ass.
Si, it's very common.
Bass sets... and sets... and sets again.
You understand that once this hearing has established Roger's permanent placement status, his welfare will forever forward be determined by this court.
I understand.
And you consulted a lawyer?
Look, lady, I get what I'm doing. The kid's not mine anymore. Not proud of it. There isn't anything that could change my mind about it either.

[Roger sees an angel, but can't let David know about it]
Go buy the kids nachos.
*Anything*... but nachos.
Buy them Angels jackets.
It's ninety degrees out here.
Get your butt up there, *now!*
[David leaves]
You can't go through life thinking everyone you meet will one day let you down. Because if you do, a very bad thing will happen. You'll end up like me.
[first lines]
Roger, do you believe in heaven?
I guess. That's where they said my mom went.
Are you crackin' up, or is this a repeat of Cincinnati?
No, no, it's nothing like that.

[to George]
It musta been those chili dogs I ate before the game. The third one tasted kind of funny.

[to Roger as he drinks his Coke at a game]
Please don't drink me.
And Ben Williams makes a miraculous catch!
Holy cow!
How did he do that?
How'd he do that? HOW DID HE DO THAT?

[Knox and Williams watch a replay of Williams' amazing catch]
Nice catch yesterday, man. How did it feel? Or did it all happen so fast you don't even remember?
I felt weightless, like somebody had me by the arms, Skip. How did I do that?
Okay, we have three photo ops. It'll be quick.
Give them publicity stills. It'll be quicker.
They want a picture with *you*. They're all kids.
I HATE KIDS.

[not surprised]
Yeah, I guessed that.

[after Roger tells him about the real Angels]
Great! A psycho kid. David, you'd think they'd screen these people.
Any loss is hard.

But this one really got to you. You leave Cincinnati after ten years of winning ball clubs - although the really big one always seemed to be just out of reach - and you come out here to manage our Angels. Now, expectations were high that you could turn this team around. But that just doesn't seem to be happening.
Season's only half-over, Ranch.
And your club's in last place.
You oughtta know how one incident can change the course of events.
Well, you know, you play the game. You take your chances. Sometimes, you're just in the wrong place at the wrong time.
Yeah, you're an expert at that.
I could say the same about you.
Well, actions speak louder than words.
I've got nothing left.
Yeah, you do. You've got one strike left.
[turns to dugout, Roger walks out flapping his arms like angel's wings]
You've got an angel with you right now... just got here, and he's going to help.
The kid sees an angel?
Yeah, he must. That's the signal.
[gradually all players and crowd, even those in the office, stand and flap their arms]

[moved by seeing the crowd]
It could happen.
Okay.

[laughs]
Go get 'em for the championship!

[Repeated line]
It could happen!
Gimme the ball, Gates.
It ain't my fault. You need a new outfield!
You're outta here, GIVE ME THE BALL!
You want the ball? Here you go...
[makes as though to hand it over then tosses it]
Go get it. Want my glove?
[repeats the gesture]
Go get it!

[broadcasting offscreen]
Gates has thrown the ball and his glove into the stands.

[jumps Gates]
Get outta here! You're finished, Gates! You're washed up! You'll never pitch again!

[on when Mel can play again]
How's never sound? You blew your arm out, played on too many pain pills.
Pain pills? You were the one stuffin' them down my throat five years ago in Cincinnati.
Hey, it was your decision to swallow 'em! I had a brain. When you couldn't play, I transferred you. Got rid of you. I never thought I'd get stuck with you again.
We do it all summer / And it's a big bummer / No matter who we play / We give the game away. / 'Cause we can't win / That would be a sin / We even lose the games / before they begin...
Save it, Mapel!

[flinging the stats book and pamphlet the assistant offers him aside, after Clark's first two pitches fail miserably]
I'm checking to see if Dan Prince pulled a muscle during his warmup tosses. There has to be some reason why Knox would make such a radical change. I have personally checked the stats, sports fans, and Mel Clark has not started a game in this decade.
You feeling any better today, George?
Why would I be feeling any better?
Commissioner's fined you $5,000 for you jumping Gates. And word has it Ranch is pressing civil charges for you popping him.

[grins]
Come to think of it, I have felt better since I slugged Wilder.
Your pistol's smoking, pal.
I hadn't made the connection.
I know you two have been at each other's throats for a long time.
Yeah, we've been at each others throats since he spiked my knee and ruined my career.
Accidents happen, George.
It wasn't an accident. When you slide into a catcher with your nails up, it's on purpose.
Now, don't go making more cow pies to step in, George. You've already got enough manure on your boots now. Control yourself today.
Hemmerling for Mitchell? Go back to Cincinnati!
You're blind as a horse's ass.
And Williams and Norton collide, and the catch is blown.
Boy, they're bad!

[to George]
Four angels came out of the sky and they picked up Ben Williams.
I've got to ask you something. Do you believe in angels?
What have angels got to do with you being out of bed?
In baseball we use signals. Make some kind of signal. I can't come over here every couple of seconds.
I'll go like that, okay?
No doubt he's tiring, Wally, and Knox knows it. Ball one.
Did you see that?
Yeah! Awesome!
They were just sucked down right from the sky.
Who?
Those guys. Those guys... in sparkling pajamas.
What are you talking about, Roger? What guys in sparkling pajamas?

[after dinner]
Next time I'll try lasagna. You guys like lasagna?
No... What is it?
I can't believe it - he's got an angel!
I guess no matter how many times you hear that song played in a Major League stadium, on a warm afternoon, it's still emotionally evocative.
Drop dead. I got sunscreen in my eye.

I can't explain it, but something has happened to my players this year. Something... that's changed the way they play... and the way I manage. You can call it faith, you can call it angels, you can call it whatever you want. That's all I have to say.
I got nothing left.
Yeah, you do. You got one strike left.
[Roger and JP come out of the dugout flapping their arms]
You got an angel with you right now. He just got here, and he's going to help you.
The kid sees an angel?
Yeah, he must. That's the signal.
[the crowd and players begin flapping their arms like angel wings]
Good helping.
[soon everybody except Ranch is flapping their arms]
Okay.
Go get 'em for the championship!
You're Roger's mom?
Nope.
Aunt? Grandma?
No, we're not related. This is a short-term foster care facility, I run it. Roger is a ward of the state.
I see. So Roger, he's got a wild imagination? Always coming up with stories?
No actually, he's very grounded. Truth is most kids who are taken away from their parents by the court system, have a good handle on reality.
